title: Infectious canine hepatitis
text:
Infectious canine hepatitis (ICH) is an <a href="acute%20%28medical%29">acute</a> liver infection in dogs caused by Canine mastadenovirus A, formerly called "Canine adenovirus 1" (CAV-1). CAV-1 also causes disease in <a href="Gray%20Wolf">wolves</a>, <a href="coyote">coyote</a>s, and <a href="bear">bear</a>s, and <a href="encephalitis">encephalitis</a> in <a href="fox">fox</a>es. The <a href="virus">virus</a> is spread in the feces, urine, blood, saliva, and nasal discharge of infected dogs. It is contracted through the mouth or nose, where it replicates in the <a href="tonsil">tonsil</a>s. The virus then infects the <a href="liver">liver</a> and <a href="kidney">kidney</a>s. The <a href="incubation%20period">incubation period</a> is 4 to 7 days.
Symptoms include <a href="fever">fever</a>, depression, loss of appetite, coughing, and a tender abdomen. <a href="Cornea">Cornea</a>l <a href="edema">edema</a> and signs of liver disease, such as <a href="jaundice">jaundice</a>, vomiting, and <a href="hepatic%20encephalopathy">hepatic encephalopathy</a>, may also occur. Severe cases will develop <a href="coagulation">bleeding</a> disorders, which can cause <a href="hematoma">hematoma</a>s to form in the mouth. Death can occur secondary to this or the liver disease. However, most dogs recover after a brief illness, although chronic corneal edema and kidney lesions may persist.
Diagnosis is made by recognizing the combination of symptoms and abnormal blood tests that occur in infectious canine hepatitis. A rising <a href="serology">antibody titer</a> to CAV-1 is also seen. The disease can be confused with <a href="canine%20parvovirus">canine parvovirus</a> because both will cause a low <a href="white%20blood%20cell">white blood cell</a> count and bloody diarrhea in young, unvaccinated dogs.
Treatment is symptomatic. Most dogs recover spontaneously without treatment. Prevention is through <a href="vaccine">vaccination</a> (<a href="ATCvet">ATCvet</a> code and various combination vaccines). Most combination <a href="vaccine">vaccine</a>s for dogs contain a modified canine adenovirus type-2. CAV-2 is one of the causes of respiratory infections in dogs, but it is similar enough to CAV-1 that vaccine for one creates <a href="immunity%20%28medical%29">immunity</a> for both. CAV-2 vaccine is much less likely to cause side effects than CAV-1 vaccine. One study has shown the vaccine to have a duration of immunity of at least four years.
CAV-1 is destroyed in the environment by steam cleaning and <a href="quaternary%20ammonium%20cation">quaternary ammonium compound</a>s. Otherwise, the virus can survive in the environment for months in the right conditions. It can also be released in the urine of a recovered dog for up to a year.
